summary: The Timothy J. Barber Act, introduced in the House of Representatives, directs the Secretary of Labor to study the effectiveness of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) spending on technical and compliance assistance related to heat-related illnesses. The study will assess effectiveness at national and regional levels and explore ways to improve spending efficiency. The Secretary is required to submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment, including recommendations for legislative or other actions.
